titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went round according to the custom of the Country, and left cards of visitation at the houses of the President of the National Assembly, Secretary to the Committee of external relations, all the members of that Committee, the other foreign Ministers, and my acquaintance in general.— Took afterwards a walk towards Delft returning by the Ryswick road.— Mr: Macqueen here after dinner. Evening at Mr: Cneiff’s. A single party at whist.

2. Visit this morning from Mr: Cneiff— Spent the forenoon in arranging and settling my accounts, a thing to which I have too long intermitted a due attention. Walk in the wood. Weather remarkably moderate. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.

3. At my accounts again in the forenoon.— Walk towards Delft— Evening at home. Reading papers in the Rambler— A few Letters of Cicero to Atticus—and the remainder of Plutarch’s life of Cicero. Every one of the Letters needs a dissertation to be understood. The Abbé de St: Réal’s french Notes are useful, but often diffuse, and wide from the subject. His translation is sometimes inaccurate.

4. Continuing the settlement of my accounts and nearly finished the business.— Am to be cautious in future not to let them run so long in arrear.— Walk, alone.— Evening with Mr: & Madam Veerman at the Dutch play. The hermit of Formentera—and Jerome Pointu.— performance tolerable. finished earlier than before.— Count Loewenhielm returned.

5. Visit this forenoon to Count Loewenhielm. Neither he nor the Chevalier de Reuterswerd at home. Met the latter.— Half an hour at the Convention. Walk— Met Mr: Levsen, and walked with him as far as Ryswick.— At Mr: Noël’s party a short time in the Evening.
6. Weather cold again.— Walk in the wood. Mr: Bourne and Captain Mackay dined with us. Mackay going to Paris.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.— Twelfth night or Jour des Rois.— Music.
7. Walk to Ryswick.— Evening at Mr: Bosset’s. Company considerably large.— Cards. Quadrill with Madame Bosset, Reuterswerd and Levsen.— home between 10 and 11.
8. Cold weather.— Writing.— Walk to Ryswick.— Returning met Mr: Veerman; his inmate Geervliet, and Hache.— Evening at his house.— Music.

9. Letters from London. Forenoon spent in answering them.— Usual walk.— Evening at the french play. Toberne ou le Pecheur Suedois. An indifferent Opera. Les deux Avares, a good thing, and an old acquaintance.— Mr: Bourne here in the forenoon.

10. I spend my days at present in such continued regularity, as afford no materials for observation.— Expedited my Letters for London, and all the rest of my time till dinner writing to Pitcairn.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s— Small party. Cards.— Whist with her and Reuterswerd. Found the evil consequence of omitting a single day’s exercise.

11. Visit in the forenoon from four friends or Quakers, religious travellers. They wanted Passports: but one of them being an Englishman I could not furnish him with one.— From Bielfeld—and walk with him.— Evening at M: de Schubart’s, Large Company— Cards— Reversi.— Did not stay to supper.

12. Weather moderated somewhat. Busily employed in writing.— Walk alone before dinner. Called in the Evening upon Madame Dumas, and afterwards upon her daughter Madam Veerman— Home in due Season. Finished reading the second book of Cicero’s Letters of Atticus.

13. Letters from my father.— Octr: 28.— Wrote to Pitcairn— Walk to Ryswick. Visit this afternoon from Mr: W. P. White of Boston. Brought a Letter of Introduction from Mr: Johnson.— Goes to Amsterdam to morrow morning.— Evening at home.

14. Weather very moderate.— Visit from Mr: Bosset.— N.B. to write to Hall.— Walk to Ryswick. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s.— Cards.— Whist. Count Loewenhielm, M: de Martilly and Reuterswerd.— The Count studies politeness as usual.— unlucky sometimes in his compliments.

15. Writing to my father. Walk to the bridge beyond Ryswick.— Mr: Macqueen here in the afternoon— Evening at home— Endeavouring at self-examination, self-correction and self-government.— Read some very good papers in the Rambler. Read the 3d: book of Cicero to Atticus.

16. Remarkable moderate and fine day. Walk to the Bridge beyond Ryswick. Mr: Macqueen called after dinner. Evening, at Mr: Veerman’s.— Went to see him at the Corps de Garde.— Walk afterwards with Madame. Home after eleven. Began reading the 4th: book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus.
17. Pleasant and moderate weather still.— Writing to my father.— Walk to the House in the wood.— My brother went to the Ball.— Evening at home.— Reading Cicero.

18. Visit this forenoon from Reuterswerd.— Walk to the Bridge towards Ryswick. Reading this afternoon a few papers of the Rambler and some Letters of Cicero to Atticus. To go through these is a task almost desperate.— Evening at Count Loewenhielm’s.— Cards. Whist, with Madame Cneiff, and Reuterswerd.— Employment of my time at present very regular.
19. Wrote to my mother.— Usual walk.— Reading Cicero to Atticus.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s.— Cards Reversi, with a Lady, M. d’Anduaga, and General Rewbell.

div.p: 20. Letter at length from the Secretary of the Treasury. Relieves me from part of my anxiety.— Forenoon answering it.— Letters to the Bankers at Amsterdam and to my friend at London— Finished reading the 4th: book of Cicero’s Letters to Atticus. Here I must stop for the present.— My french translation goes no further, and I have no Edition of Cicero with a commentary at hand. It is impossible to read these Letters without one or the other. I know not of any Latin classick more difficult to be understood.

21. Weather has been for several days dull, but not very cold.— Walk beyond Ryswick. Time spent as usual— Mr: Macqueen in the afternoon.— Evening at home.— Devote too much of my time to the drudgery of Literature.— Indolence of mind— I know not whether I shall ever vanquish it.

22. Visit this forenoon from Mr: Monroe. He arrived last Evening from Paris. Accompanied by a french Officer.— Usual walk beyond Ryswick.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s— Large party.— Cards. Quadrill and Whist.— Home early.

23. Visit this forenoon to Mr: Monroe— His Lady with him— Left his daughter at Paris.— He spends about a week here, and proposes after making the tour of this Country to return to Paris, before he goes home.— Went with him and Mr: De Witt the Minister of this Republic in Switzerland to the Assembly. Debates upon the Constitution.— Dined at Mr: Noël’s. Mr: & Mrs: Monroe: the french Officer who came with them and Mr: Hahn. Evening at Mlle: Laurenzi’s.— Whist, with Madm Cneiff, M. Chestret and a Gentleman whose name I know not. Letters this morning from the Secretary of the Treasury, to Decr: 6.— Gave me great relief.

24. Fine weather.— Walk to the House in the wood. Dined at Mr: Hahn’s, with Mr: & Mrs: Monroe. Messrs: Hartogh, Van Eck & Van Leyden.— Evening at Mr: Van Leyden’s. Very large party.— Whist with Mr: Van Leyden’s Mother— Mr: Monroe & General Rewbell.— Bielfeld told me that the french Newspapers arrived this day announce that Mr: Jefferson is chosen President of the United States.
25. Writing all the forenoon, and lost even the time for my customary walk. Evening at Madam Mersen’s. Company not very numerous. Quadrill with Madam Amman, another Lady and Mr: Mersen.

26. A number of letters from America. Whole forenoon again employed in writing. Business presses hard upon me. Dined at Mr: Van Leyden’s. Mr: & Mrs: Monroe. Mr: Noel. Mr: & Madm: Hahn. After dinner the General De Gent came in. Evening at Mr: Noël’s party.— Large as usual.— Visit in the morning to Mr: Monroe. Carried Mr: Short’s medal to him.

27. Second large packet of Letters from England and America.— M. d’Anduaga called on me. Dined with him. Mr: & Mrs: Monroe. Messrs: Schubart & Van der Goes and their Ladies.— Evening at Mr: Van Staphorst’s. Reversi with Mr: Noël & Mr: & Madam Schimmelpenninck. Did not stay to supper.

28. Another packet of Letters English and American.— Visit from Mr: Monroe.— From Mr: Havart, who brought me a number of Baltimore papers. Conversation with him.— Couple of Quakers called on me again in the morning. Forenoon thus slipped away. Long walk after dinner. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Backgammon with Mr: Loder.

29. Visit this forenoon from Mr: Beeldemaker.— Several more Letters. Began at length to write in my turn. Found no time for walking. Dined at Count Loewenhielm’s. Party small but pleasant.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Company numerous. Quadrill with Mlle: Dumoulin, M. de Loewenhielm & Bielfeld.

30. At length have a day of respite from the flood of letters, pouring from all parts.— Writing to England. Employed the whole forenoon and part of the Evening. Had Engaged at a party of Madme: Pallavicini’s, but sent my excuses to finish my Letter.

31. Forenoon very busily employed in writing to Pitcairn— Mr: Schermerhorn dined with us, and went in the Evening with my brother to the ball.— Evening at home myself.— Constant occupation to very little purpose.

Day. Rise in the morning at about 7. Translate two pages of History from Tacitus. Breakfast at about ten.— Afterwards till 2. Dressing receiving or paying visits or writing Letters. Dine between 3 and 4. After dinner read a few papers of the Rambler. Walk of three or four miles immediately before or after dinner. Evening generally in company and at cards. Seldom at home and reading a few of Cicero’s Letters.— A profound anxiety has taken possession of my mind. The situation of two objects the nearest to my Heart; my Country and my Father press continually upon my reflections— They engross every thought and almost overpower every faculty.— The struggle is painful indeed amid such sensations to bear a cheerful countenance to the world, to stifle every apprehension and repress every rising sigh.— A sullen gloom hangs upon futurity— May the merciful disposer of all Events, avert the approaching terror, and dispel the threatening tempest.— For myself I ask only Virtue and Fortitude.— Virtue to discharge all the duties of life, and Fortitude to bear whatever destiny awaits me. For my father and my Country, my supplications to Eternal wisdom and goodness, comprehend the issue and result of action and pray for their welfare and prosperity no less than for the means that tend to procure them.
